title: AITA for refusing to let my sister use my car?
self_text: My sister (32) and I have a strained relationship. She’s consistently relied on me for rides to work and errands, and frankly, it’s exhausting. She’s unemployed and struggles with chronic depression, leading to frequent requests for transportation. Recently, she asked to borrow my car for a weekend trip to visit her estranged husband—a man I strongly disapprove of. I firmly declined, citing concerns about her judgment and safety. She argued that she needs transportation to maintain any semblance of independence and that I’m deliberately isolating her. I reiterated that I’m prioritizing my own wellbeing and resources. Now she’s accusing me of being selfish and intentionally sabotaging her life. I genuinely believe she needs professional help, not reliance on my car. Am I the asshole?

title: Robot Vacuum Rebellion
self_text: My Roomba has started aggressively avoiding specific spots in the living room, repeatedly bumping into furniture and spinning in circles. It seems to be targeting a rug with a slightly darker shade of blue than the surrounding carpet. I’ve tried resetting it, cleaning it thoroughly, and adjusting the settings, but nothing works. It's like it *despises* that rug. I suspect it’s staging a silent protest.

title: AITA for refusing to return a library book overdue by 3 months?
self_text: My local library has a strict policy about fines accruing daily. I borrowed a cookbook about six months ago and completely forgot about it. I just realized it's overdue and they've slapped me with a hefty fine. I attempted to explain my lapse in memory, emphasizing I hadn't intentionally neglected the book, but the librarian was incredibly rigid and insisted on the fine being paid immediately. I argued that the library should prioritize assisting patrons rather than aggressively pursuing minor overdue fees, especially considering the book wasn't damaged and I could easily renew it if I remembered. She said it’s library policy and that I’m responsible for managing my own borrowing records. I just paid the fine, but I feel deeply frustrated and believe the system is unnecessarily punitive. Am I the asshole for questioning the fairness of the fine?

title: My neighbor is blasting music at 3am
self_text: I’m losing my mind. My neighbor is consistently playing incredibly loud music at 3am, and I have no idea how to approach the situation.

title: AITA for refusing to bake cookies for my in-laws?
self_text: My husband’s parents are coming over for Christmas Eve dinner. They *always* demand I bake their favorite oatmeal raisin cookies. Every. Single. Year. I’ve politely declined for the last three years, citing time constraints and a preference for simpler desserts. They’ve upped the pressure each time, suggesting I “shouldn’t burden myself” and that it’s “just cookies.” My husband supports me in saying no, but his mom is now actively hinting that she’ll “make something else” if I don’t contribute. I feel like I’m being unreasonable, but baking dozens of cookies for people who consistently minimize my efforts feels incredibly draining.

title: Weird Thing I Saw Today
self_text: Walking down the street, I saw a squirrel meticulously burying a single, perfectly formed croissant. It repeated the process three times. I stared in disbelief. Was this some sort of bizarre ritual?

title: AITA for refusing to donate to a fundraising campaign for a local animal shelter?
self_text: I’ve been donating to the Happy Paws Animal Shelter for years – monthly, consistently. However, I recently saw a crowdfunding campaign for them, claiming they desperately need funds for urgent veterinary care. I clicked through, read the details, and frankly, I felt it was excessive. The campaign highlighted incredibly graphic images of animals with severe injuries, and the proposed costs were astronomical. I’m a practical person, and I questioned whether the shelter was truly managing its resources effectively or if this was just a desperate ploy for donations. I decided *not* to contribute, citing concerns about transparency and the potential misuse of funds. My sister, who runs the shelter, confronted me, accusing me of being callous and uncaring. She insists that every dollar counts and that I should support the organization regardless of my doubts. I defended my decision, emphasizing my long-standing contributions and my belief that I’ve supported them in the past. Now, I’m feeling increasingly guilty and anxious about the fallout. AITA?

title: I broke up with my girlfriend.
self_text: I broke up with my girlfriend, and I'm feeling pretty awful. She said she felt suffocated by my constant need to plan activities and that I was controlling. I genuinely just wanted to spend time with her, but I realize now I was imposing my preferences on her.  Should I apologize?

A side note, they’ve been doing construction on the highway in our area and recently built a new part of the highway and put in a big new stop light. They just changed the traffic pattern so that the old highway is now non-accessible. Jessie explained that she’d been out of town for the week (early Thanksgiving) and the old highway had still been open. She said that the new intersection suddenly appeared out of nowhere and she ran a red light and nearly t-boned another car.   That’s definitely scary, I can understand her being upset. title: AITA for refusing to give my ex’s kid a ride?
self_text: My ex and I broke up six months ago amicably. We have a seven-year-old son, Leo, who lives with his mom. We alternate weekends, and I always drop him off and pick him up. However, his mom recently asked if I could start driving him to soccer practice every Tuesday and Thursday. She said she’s swamped with work and it would be a huge help. I declined, citing that I’m already stretched thin with my own commitments and it’s not something I’m willing to commit to consistently. She got upset and said I was being selfish and uncaring. I told her I was happy to help occasionally, but not establish a regular routine. She’s now threatening to withhold Leo from me on the upcoming weekend. A friend suggested I cave to avoid a battle, but I don’t want to get dragged back into a constant conflict. AITA?

title: AITA for refusing to give my neighbor a ride to the airport?
self_text: My neighbor, Mark, reached out yesterday saying he needed a ride to the airport for a flight to Florida. Heard he’s going to visit his grandkids. He’s a generally nice guy, but he’s a bit of a mess – always leaving his lawn overgrown, overflowing bins, and generally not keeping things tidy. I politely declined, citing I was busy with errands and don’t typically offer rides. He then started arguing, saying I was being selfish and inconsiderate, and that he’d been relying on me in the past. He even threatened to report me to the HOA for “lack of community spirit.” I stood my ground and reiterated that I wasn’t obligated to provide transportation. He’s been passive aggressive ever since, muttering to me when I see him and leaving slightly unpleasant notes on my porch. AITA for prioritizing my own schedule and avoiding someone who consistently creates minor inconveniences?

title: WIBTA if I uninvited my friend to a party that was her idea?
self_text: Gonna try to keep it vague as idk if this friend has reddit, also I'm on mobile.  C=friend So C had an idea for me to throw a thanksgiving party with some friends, and of course I invited her, I considered her my best friend, and it was her idea.  Well now I'm kinda seeing C in a new light. It's like she doesnt care about me at all, or any of her friends. She is only about herself. I have some really bad mental health issues, and I dont vent to her a lot, just because I understand a lot of it is too much and overwhelming for her. In the rare times I do vent to her, however, she always responds with "oh" or "I'm sorry" and then changes the subject to what ever man she is seeing at the time, or what ever issue she is having at the time. I'm also finding out she does this with all of her friends, and that's why I'm really her only close friend, cuz no one likes it. I think I could be over reacting? Maybe I'm just being too sensitive and this is just how friends are, or she cant handle my vents but hasnt said it directly to her. I'm not sure, I always ask before venting, and she always gives me the okay, so I'm just not sure.  So would I be the asshole if I uninvited her? Or am I just being too dramatic? Edit: I'm the asshole I get it. I’ll stop bugging him about it

title: Pizza Delivery Driver Nightmare
self_text: I work as a pizza delivery driver for a small local shop. Tonight, I delivered to a house with no doorbell, no visible entrance, and a really creepy vibe. He paid with a twenty dollar bill and just stared at me intensely before slamming the door. I’ve had weird deliveries before, but this was genuinely unsettling. I’m considering quitting.

title: AITA for refusing to participate in a neighborhood potluck?
self_text: My neighbors organized a potluck for the upcoming block party. I generally don’t socialize much, and I rarely attend neighborhood events. However, they specifically asked me to contribute a dish, emphasizing that it would be "great to have you involved." I politely declined, citing a busy schedule and a preference for solitary activities. title: AITA for refusing to pay for my sister’s college housing?
self_text: Fake account as I don't want my real reddit tied to this family issue. My grandmother passed away this summer and in her will I was left a small home in the college town that I live in. This house was where I (as well as my siblings and some other members of my family) lived while we pursued our degree(s). She (my grandmother) made rent equal to expenses + a bit extra to cover regular maintenance; it was a stellar deal for college, and it holds a lot of fond memories—I feel very fortunate to have received this house and intend on continuing her legacy with the space. I have told my family (there are 4 remaining cousins who are not college aged yet), that I intend on continuing renting the house out at cost to family members if they chose to pursue a degree at the college where this house is located (or if they choose to take a job in the area during their "college age years"). Here is where the dilemma comes in, when I made this announcement, I received a call from a cousin who is currently attending a different college that is nowhere near the home I inherited. She wanted to know how much I intended on sending her for her housing when she moved off campus next fall—as my grandmother did give some money to her grandchildren who chose not to go to college where the house was (not nearly enough to make the deal that the house was, but from my understanding it was equal to a couple hundred dollars a month). And when I told her I was not planning on sending ANY money for her housing, she went off screaming that I was disgracing my grandmother’s legacy and that she would have wanted me to fulfill the entire legacy of college housing generosity. I am not a wealthy person—I did not receive any money in the inheritance -- just the house. And even that, I have had to spend a fair amount of money in repairs to get the home back to prime condition as non-family tenants had moved out during her passing and they took advantage of the lack of supervision during the legal red tape surrounding the house. I told her that even if I wanted to fulfill the whole legacy, I didn’t have the money and that that was it. Now I have family members calling stating that I am now forcing their children to choose this school near the house, when everyone else got to choose. I feel guilty—but it’s not like they can’t go to another school, they will just have to pay for 100% of their housing—AITA?

title: AITA for telling my sister she needs to stop putting all of her problems on me?
self_text: My sister (32) and I (24) have a pretty ok relationship. For the past 2 years my family has gone through a lot of issues with our restaurant going on fire, dealing with terrible contractors/attorneys who left and stole our money, a lawsuit against our tenants, lease problems etc.   My sister has become depressed especially because the issues and having to work at the hospital during the pandemic lockdown. But, I don’t think it is right for her to treat me and others the way she does.  She rants and puts all of her problems on others (ex: she would complain about a situation and spend so long talking) without thinking about how it affects others. She never asks how we are doing. She does this thing where she would text me “Hi, how are you doing?”, I would respond, and then she would just tell me something completely unrelated to that conversation and start talking about the issue she is having. Whenever she rants about her problems, I try to offer a solution or advice, and it never works. (ex: she is stressed and doesn’t want to talk about the lawsuit. I said I would talk to my parents and then I would just relay the information so that she doesn’t need to talk to them and we don’t need to pester our parents by asking the same questions. 1 hour later, she calls my parents and asks the same questions I asked 5 minutes earlier.)  She doesn't have the best relationship with my dad. My dad has a hot temper and can lash out on others, but he does have a good heart and he doesn’t mean to do that. I told him that even if I wanted to fulfill the whole legacy, I didn’t have the money and that that was it. Now I have family members calling stating that I am now forcing their children to choose this school near the house, when everyone else got to choose.  I feel guilty–but it’s not like they can’t go to another school, they will just have to pay for 100% of their housing—AITA?   She is recently engaged (6 months ago) and whenever she is in a bad mood, she would tell her fiancé that she doesn’t want to get married and tries to give him the ring back. She has done this more than 3 times. She also jokes about getting divorced, which makes no sense, because why are you joking about something like this? I told her she shouldn’t joke about divorce if she doesn’t mean it, but if she does mean it, then she should just give the ring back, end things and stop messing with her fiancé. She just started laughing, said some rude comments to me and made me feel so stupid.   I have told my mom that she needs to talk to my sister, but my mom keeps pushing it back, saying she is too depressed, so we have to keep quiet for now.  But my mom has been saying this for the past two years.  I’m depressed and have really bad anxiety, but I keep it hidden from my family because I am known to be the cheerful, happy one. I can’t tell my parents how I am feeling, because it would destroy them.  AITA?

title: AITA for refusing to bake cookies for my neighbor’s kids?
self_text: My neighbor, a single mom, asked if I could bake a batch of cookies for her kids’ birthday party this weekend. I politely declined, explaining I’m swamped with work and don’t really have time for baking. She then insisted I make a specific type of cookie—chocolate chip—which is honestly not my favorite. She seemed genuinely disappointed and said it would mean a lot to the kids. I felt pressured, but I firmly reiterated that I couldn’t, and she’s been giving me passive-aggressive comments about how “busy” I am ever since.

title: AITA for not wanting to eat out on my Birthday?
self_text: Me (16f) recently got into an argument with my Older brother (21) on my birthday for my birthday I just wanted to stay at home and just spend time with my family whilst my brother who very much loves to go out and eat all the time. We’ve been clashing literally every day. My sister (32) and I have a pretty ok relationship. For the past 2 years my family has gone through a lot of issues with our restaurant going on fire, dealing with terrible contractors/attorneys who left and stole our money, a lawsuit against our tenants, lease problems etc.   My sister has become depressed especially because the issues and having to work at the hospital during the pandemic lockdown. But, I don’t think it is right for her to treat me and others the way she does.  She rants and puts all of her problems on others (ex: she would complain about a situation and spend so long talking) without thinking about how it affects others. She never asks how we are doing. She does this thing where she would text me “Hi, how are you doing?”, I would respond, and then she would just tell me something completely unrelated to that conversation and start talking about the issue she is having. Whenever she rants about her problems, I try to offer a solution or advice, and it never works. (ex: she is stressed and doesn’t want to talk about the lawsuit. I said I would talk to my parents and then I would just relay the information so that she doesn’t need to talk to them and we don’t need to pester our parents by asking the same questions).  She doesn't have the best relationship with my dad. My dad has a hot temper and can lash out on others, but he does have a good heart and he doesn’t mean to do that. She always tells my mom to divorce my dad or tells me that she hates him. It is difficult on me to hear these things because I am unsure how to respond to them. Also when anything bad happens (my parents fight, something with the lawsuit/lease/building is delayed), she acts like the world is on fire. It is so bad to the point where my parents and I feel like she can’t handle anything anymore because she reacts so poorly, but then gets angry if we don’t tell her anything.   She is recently engaged (6 months ago) and whenever she is in a bad mood, she would tell her fiancé that she doesn’t want to get married and tries to give him the ring back. She has done this more than 3 times. I told her

title: AITA for refusing to participate in a mandatory office team-building exercise?
self_text: I work in a relatively small marketing agency. Lately, management has been pushing a lot of “team-building” activities—trust falls, escape rooms, goofy challenges—all designed to supposedly boost morale and collaboration. We’re all overworked and stressed, and honestly, most of us just want to do our jobs and go home.   Yesterday, they announced a “wilderness survival simulation” – a full-day event at a nearby outdoor facility involving navigating, building shelters, and foraging for food (fake food, obviously, but still). Everyone was *required* to attend.   I politely declined, citing a pre-existing commitment (which is partially true – I have a doctor’s appointment, but it’s a routine check-up and I could reschedule). My supervisor gave me a vaguely disapproving look and said something about “understanding the importance of team cohesion.”   Several colleagues have already signed up and are excitedly discussing strategies and gear. I overheard one saying, “It’ll be hilarious!”   I feel like I’m being singled out for not participating, and frankly, the whole thing feels like a pointless waste of time and resources.  AITA?

title: AITA for refusing to engage with my sister’s political arguments?
self_text: My sister (38) has become incredibly invested in a specific brand of conservative politics lately. Every conversation, no matter how casual, devolves into a debate about various policies and ideologies. She’s persistent, frequently sharing articles and opinions, and genuinely seems frustrated when I don’t reciprocate her enthusiasm. I politely disagree with her viewpoints, offering reasoned counterarguments when I feel it’s warranted, but she consistently dismisses my concerns as “naive” or “not understanding the complexities of the situation.” Lately, she’s been actively trying to provoke a reaction, phrasing her statements in a deliberately confrontational manner. I’ve started intentionally avoiding discussing politics with her, but she brings it up anyway, often in front of other family members, making me feel uncomfortable and judged. My parents seem to encourage her behavior, suggesting I “should be more open-minded.” I feel like I'm being unfairly pressured to conform to her worldview and that our relationship is strained by this constant ideological battle. AITA for prioritizing my own emotional wellbeing and limiting our interactions?

title: My Roommate Keeps Leaving Dirty Dishes Everywhere
self_text: We’ve been living together for six months, and it’s become a constant battle. My roommate consistently leaves dirty dishes piled up in the sink and on the counter for days. I’ve politely asked him to wash them, and he brushes it off saying he’ll get to it “later.” It’s creating a disgusting environment, attracting bugs, and honestly, it’s incredibly frustrating. I’m considering talking to our landlord about it, but I’d rather resolve it directly if possible. AITA for being increasingly irritated by this habit?

title: Terrible Restaurant Experience
self_text: Went to a new Italian place downtown tonight. Service was incredibly slow – waited over an hour for our entrees. When the waiter finally brought them, one dish was completely cold and the other was burnt. We politely flagged down a manager who shrugged and said “well, it’s busy.” Offered to comp the meal, but he insisted on charging us full price. Seriously considering leaving a scathing Yelp review, but I’m hesitant to escalate unnecessarily.

title: AI generated art
self_text: I've been experimenting with Midjourney and Stable Diffusion lately, and I'm obsessed. I've managed to generate some incredibly detailed and surreal landscapes that are genuinely breathtaking. However, I’m starting to feel a strange disconnect. It's like I’m witnessing beauty without *creating* it in the traditional sense. Like I’m just prompting a machine to manifest something I imagine, rather than pouring my own skill and vision into it. Anyone else experiencing this feeling – a sort of artistic envy mixed with awe for the technology?

title: AITA for telling my husband he's being unreasonable?
self_text: My husband (42M) has been incredibly stressed about a minor issue at work – a disagreement with a colleague regarding a project deadline. It escalated into him snapping at me repeatedly over the past week, criticizing my choices, and generally being irritable. I’ve tried to be supportive, offering to help with chores and reminding him to relax, but he just seems to double down on his frustration. Tonight, he accused me of not caring about his problems and said I was deliberately trying to make him unhappy. I calmly explained that I *do* care and that his reactions are disproportionate to the situation. He then dismissed my concerns and walked away. I felt like I was constantly battling him and couldn't understand why he couldn't just take a deep breath.  I told him he's being unreasonably stressed and that his behavior is hurting our relationship. He got visibly angry and said I was attacking him. I’m starting to feel unheard and frustrated. Is it unreasonable of me to express concern about his behavior, or am I contributing to the conflict?

title: AITA for refusing to donate to a political campaign?
self_text: My family has a deeply ingrained aversion to donating to political campaigns. It’s a longstanding belief that politicians are inherently corrupt and that money unduly influences their decisions. We’ve never contributed to any campaign, regardless of party affiliation. Recently, my sibling hosted a fundraising event for a local candidate and strongly encouraged me to contribute. They argued that supporting the candidate was essential to enacting positive change. I politely declined, reiterating our stance, but my sibling became visibly frustrated and accused me of being complacent and unwilling to engage in civic duty. They implied I was prioritizing my principles over contributing to solutions. I maintain that our approach is consistent with our values and that donating to campaigns perpetuates the problem we oppose. Now, my sibling is actively trying to convince me to reconsider, suggesting I’m being selfish and narrow-minded. AITA for sticking to our established beliefs regarding political donations?

title: Cats in boxes
self_text: My cat spends approximately 90% of his time curled up in cardboard boxes. Seriously, *any* box. Small, large, empty, full… it doesn’t matter. I’ve bought him a fancy cat bed, a heated blanket, a scratching post shaped like a castle… he ignores them all and gravitates towards the nearest box. I’ve tried discouraging it (moving the boxes, putting foil down, etc.), but he always finds them. Is this normal? Am I enabling a bizarre obsession?

title: AITA for refusing to bake cookies for my extended family?
self_text: My mom insisted I bake a huge batch of cookies for our annual holiday gathering. She said it’s “tradition” and that everyone loves my chocolate chip recipe. Honestly, I’m exhausted and overwhelmed with work. Baking a giant cookie tray takes HOURS, and I’d rather spend that time relaxing. I politely declined, suggesting we order dessert. She got incredibly upset, accusing me of being selfish and uncaring. Now she’s saying I’m ruining the holiday and that my family will be disappointed. I don’t want to fight with her, but I also don’t want to spend my precious downtime slaving over a hot oven.

title: Pizza Delivery Driver Apocalypse
self_text: Okay, this is legitimately unsettling. I’ve been delivering pizzas for DoorDash for about six months now, and the orders have been…weird. Like, *really* weird. It started subtly – requests for specific toppings arranged in bizarre patterns, unusually large quantities of garlic, a demand for pineapple *and* anchovies simultaneously.  But it's escalated. Over the last two weeks, I've delivered pizzas addressed to people who don't live at those addresses. I've had deliveries to vacant lots, abandoned buildings, and once, a wooded area.  Each time, the instructions are cryptic – “Leave it by the oak,” “Under the third brick,” “Behind the blue mailbox.”  And the tip amounts are consistently $0.  Tonight, I got a delivery to a completely unmarked, dilapidated shack in the middle of a swamp. The driver’s note said, “The Offering is complete.” I sped away, and I’m genuinely terrified.  I’ve started documenting everything, including pictures of the strange deliveries.  Has anyone else experienced anything like this? Is this just a localized phenomenon, or is something genuinely disturbing going on?  Seriously considering quitting this job.

title: My Roommate’s Pet Rock
self_text: Seriously, it’s a problem. My roommate, Liam, has adopted a small grey river rock and treats it like a child. He talks *to* it, feeds it tiny pieces of dried fruit, and has built it a miniature cardboard castle. He insists it has “personality” and spends hours meticulously arranging its accessories. I’ve politely expressed concern that he’s…obsessed, but he just shrugs and says the rock appreciates his care. It’s starting to invade the common areas, and frankly, it’s unsettling. AITA for subtly suggesting he might need to talk to someone about this?

title: AITA for refusing to do any work around the house
self_text: I (32M) and my GF (32F) have been together for 8 years. We have a 2-month-old child together and recently bought a house. Long story short, we’ve both been busting our asses on this new house to get it move-in ready for when the baby arrived. This house was disgusting and needed a lot of elbow grease, and if it weren’t for the help of her parents, it wouldn’t be anywhere near what it is today. I want to give credit where credit is due and say that she did A LOT for being pregnant, and even overdid a time or two to the point where she had to stop and lay down because she just pushes too hard when shit has to get done. All of this to say, recently I feel she has been very rude to me when it comes to getting things done. We both have been off work for several weeks to care for our newborn son, and she sees this as a time for me to get house projects done. In 6 weeks, I have, by myself, built 4 doors for our shed (with help from family members), painted/primed, said doors, installed latches and locks, done multiple yard clean-ups to keep up with leaves, patched a bunch of holes in the garage (one was 2ftx2ft in size), cleaned and painted ceiling walls and floor of the garage, and the list goes on and on. ...
